testimony: Good morning, we want to start the proceedings.  For the record, it is Wednesday the 1st of September 1999, it is a sitting of the Amnesty Committee at Durban.  It's presided over by myself, Denzil Potgieter, I'm assisted by Adv de Jager and Mr Sibanyoni.  We will be hearing the amnesty applications of Nicholas Johannes Vermeulen, the reference AM4358/96 and that of Almond Butana Nofomela, reference AM0064/96. 	Just for the record, I'm going to ask the legal representatives to place themselves on record.  We'll start with you, Mr Ramawele.
My name is R P A Ramawele, I'm appearing for Mr Nofomela.
Thank you, Mr Ramawele.  Mr Cornelius?
Thank you, Mr Chairman, Wim Cornelius acting on behalf of N J Vermeulen, the fourth applicant.
Thank you, Mr Chairman, it's Schalk Hugo, I'm acting for implicated parties, Mr E A de Kock and Simon Radebe.
Thank you, Mr Chairman, I'm Sibusiso Shezi, I'm appearing for the family of the victims.
Thank you, Mr Shezi.  Ms Patel?
Ramula Patel, Leader of Evidence, thank you.
Thank you, lady and gentlemen.  I believe that we will start off with the application of Mr Nofomela.
Mr Ramawele, do you want us to administer the oath to your client?
Thank you, please sit down.  Yes, Mr Ramawele?

Thank you, Mr Chairman.
	Mr Nofomela, is it correct that you joined the South African Police Service in 1979?
I actually now refer you to an application that you made for amnesty in respect of the Chesterville incident of June 1986.  Do you remember that?
Do you confirm the contents of your application that you made in respect of this incident?
Now just briefly, after joining the SAP in 1979, when did you become attached to the Vlakplaas unit?
I started December 1980, after leaving the college.
To come to this particular incident, I'm referring to the Chesterville incident, can you tell the hearing how did it come about that you would go to Durban, relating to this incident?

If I remember well, at the time I was Mr de Kock's driver.  I came with him from Vlakplaas to C R Swart Police Station.  I found the other group from Vlakplaas there at CR Swart Police Station.  They were based next to a place called Unit at CR Swart.  I met them there from Vlakplaas with Mr de Kock.
And Sir, when you arrived in Durban, already there were other members of Vlakplaas, who had already arrived in Durban before you came to Durban?
Did you know what those members of Vlakplaas were doing, those who came before you?

I don't know everything about them, but I was just speculating that normally when they are in Durban they normally go to the bus stops and the taxi ranks, they visit places like the stations, the townships, looking for the people whom they used to call terrorists.
And as you say you then went to Durban with Maj de Kock?
And were you travelling in a car?
Yes, we were travelling in a car, Chairperson.
Upon your arrival in Durban, what happened further?

I don't know after how many days, but there was a talk going around as we were in the Dog Unit, our base, that was Mr de Kock's utterances telling the people who were there, the people who were appointed to go to Chesterville, he was telling them to infiltrate the UDF members, they should go there and pretend as if they were ANC members.
And these were the members of Vlakplaas who were instructed to go and infiltrate the UDF?
Did they go to infiltrate the UDF?
Were you there when they made the infiltration?
I was not present, de Kock told me and Geoffrey Bosigo not to go there with those people because he had a job for us.
Now did the members come back from - did the Vlakplaas members who went to infiltrate the UDF, come back from Chesterville?
Do you know whether they made any report to any person?
Chairperson, I did not hear anything, but it was a hearsay from some of them that the infiltration was successful.
And after hearing that, what transpired?

After that there was a day or night, if I remember well, whereby they were supposed to go back there again.  That is when Mr de Kock told me specifically, myself and Geoff, that he did not wish us to be there because the people would be shot at during the incident.  They people who were being infiltrated, they were going to be shot at on that particular night.
And so he said that you were not supposed to be part of the group that went to do the shooting?
What were you supposed to do?
He told me to transport the people who were going to do the infiltration, but I should just wait under the bridge, the bridge that was there.
So did you then transport some members to Chesterville?
Up to where did you go to - or let me put it this way, where eventually did you go?

We went to Chesterville, but as a person who was transporting those people with Geoffrey Bosigo and other white men that I cannot remember and the other black police, black people.  We waited under the bridge that was leading to Chesterville, on that particular night.
You waited at that bridge, and what happened to the members whom you were transporting?
Of my memory serves me well, they left for the place, the people whom we were transporting, they went to the people that they had met with before and after that we heard gunshots.

Can you just tell the hearing, before the members left for Chesterville, were there any firearms which were issued to the members, or were they unarmed?  The members from Vlakplaas who went to Chesterville.
They were armed, they were given firearms from the Dog Unit.  That is the base that we were in.  Nortje and the other white people gave them in my presence, they gave them firearms.
What type of firearms were issued to them?
I saw the AK47 rifles and some pistols, they looked like the service pistols.  I do not remember anything else, but I'm sure that I saw the AK47 rifle.
And you said earlier that after having waited at the bridge you heard a shooting.  After hearing the shooting, what happened?
After the shooting, one of the white people told us to start the cars and the others came and they got into the cars and we left.
Do you remember who that white person was who said you must drive away?
I do not remember well, I'm not sure whether it was Mr Nortje or de Kock.
So you then drove back to - is it to CR Swart?  Is that to CR Swart Police Station?
Whilst at CR Swart Police Station, did you see the members who went into the township, did you see them?
And immediately thereafter when you saw these members, where was Maj de Kock at that stage?

I do not remember where he was when we came back, but we came together from the bridge, together with the other people who were there, but I do not remember very well what happened when we arrived at the base, but all I know is that they said the mission was successful.
And when you went to - when you transported the members and waited at the bridge, where was Maj de Kock?
He was with us and Nortje - he was driving with Nortje in his car.  That's is Mr Nortje's car.
Sorry, I don't follow.  Did you bring the members back in your car, in the kombi, those who participated in the operation or not?
We brought them back. I transported them.  I was driving the vehicle.  We waited under the bridge and they left for Chesterville and they came back, they got into the car and we went back again.
So you took them to the bridge, they left you, they came back, you picked them up and you drove them back to the police station?
Were you the only person in your car who didn't go ...(intervention)
... on the operation?  No, who didn't go on the operation.
I was not the only person who did not go to the operation.
Who waited with you in the car?
It was Mr de Kock and Mr Nortje and Geoffrey Bosigo was also there.  I cannot remember the others who did not go to the operation.
Where exactly were the other people who didn't go to the operation?
They were also waiting under the bridge with me.
You alighted from the kombi or the car you were driving and you stood underneath the bridge?

We were not using one vehicle, there were other cars, two or three cars.  The other white people were in the other cars.  The car that I'm referring to was a white kombi, the one that I had used to transport the people to Chesterville and even the black people were with me in the car, in the kombi.
In the car you were driving, were you the only person who was waiting there under the bridge?
I remember I was with Geoffrey Bosigo.
So how many other cars were there apart from your car?
As I've already said, there were two to three cars.  I cannot remember well.  There were a lot of white people there.
Are you able to say how many people waited in each of the other cars?
I cannot be certain, but I can say it was approximately five to six people.
There is a possibility that you won't remember exactly who were on the other cars?
I cannot remember all of them, but Nortje was there and Mr de Kock was also there, I am certain about that too, and Geoffrey Bosigo was also there.

Thanks, Mr Chairman.
	Now after coming back from the bridge and the members also being there, did you hear Mr de Kock speaking to the members on that day or later, about the incident?

After some time, Chairperson, Mr de Kock, I heard him saying the people have made a mistake because there are people who are still alive from the people who were shot, some of them were still alive and the incident is under investigation, a certain officer is in charge, and he even mentioned the name of the officer who was investigating and he even said the people who were involved they are going to select people who are going to make a statement and before that statement is made there should be a consultation with Nortje and the other white people he had mentioned, people who were also there and he was actually telling what was going to be said.
Is there anything further that you want to mention in respect of this incident, which is necessary?
Chairperson, that is the end, there's nothing else to say.

Thank you, Mr Chairman.
NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MR RAMAWELE

Yes, thank you, Mr Ramawele.
	Mr Nofomela, how many members of Vlakplaas participated in the infiltration?
I cannot say for sure because this incident took place some time ago, but I can still remember some of them who were present.  I cannot remember the others.
No, I'm not referring to the whole group, I'm just referring to those members who actually went into Chesterville.  How many were they?
I am saying I cannot remember them, but -I cannot remember all of them, but I can still remember some names.
Who are those that you can remember?
Tandi, I cannot remember her surname, Radebe, Paulus Magage, Susan Moekwena ...(intervention)
Susan Moekwena.  I cannot remember the others.
So it's Tandi, but you don't remember her surname ...(intervention)
Tandi Hlope or Shope.  I am not sure whether the surname was Hlope or Shope.
So there's Tandi, it appears Shosha and there's Radebe.
And there was a Susan Moekwena.
Those are the members of the group that went into Chesterville, that you can still remember?
Were they - what was their role, what was their position at Vlakplaas?
Simon Radebe was a Sergeant and the others were just askaris.
So Simon was the only one that was a member of the police at that time?
All of the others were askaris?
And were all of those that you've mentioned here, were they armed with the AK47s and the service pistols that you thought you saw?
Chairperson, they had firearms, but I saw only one AK47 rifle, I saw only one of them, but I know that they were all armed.
Do you remember the date of this incident?
Could it have been the 20th of June in 1986?
Can you remember at about what time it was that you took this group to the bridge and left them to go into Chesterville?
It was in the evening, Sir, I cannot be sure as to what time was it.
How long did you wait for them about, approximately?
I cannot say for sure, but it was quite some time.
No, it was not more than an hour, it could have been half an hour.
Now you only took these people into Chesterville once, on one occasion, this one that you're telling us about now, when shooting happened.
Did you only hear one shooting incident taking place whilst you were waiting there?
It was not one firearm that was shooting, it was just automatic firing and it was quiet after that.
Was that the only occasion on which you heard gunfire whilst you were waiting at the bridge?
Yes, thank you, Mr Nofomela.  Mr Cornelius, any questions?

Thank you, Mr Chairman.
	You obviously didn't testify at the inquest?
And you didn't supply a statement to the Special Investigation Team of the Attorney-General's office?
So you were there for six years?
Of the white members of Vlakplaas, who can you recall, names?  During that period of 1986.
I remember Dirk Coetzee, Jan Coetzee, Cronje.
Van Dyk, Vermeulen, Bosch.  I cannot remember the others, Sir.
Frank McCarter?  Can you recall the name Frank McCarter?
I am referring to Koos Vermeulen, he was a Station Commander at Bronkhorstspruit.
Oh.  Did you know N J Vermeulen, known as "Snor" Vermeulen?
Is he in this hearing today?
It has been a long time, I cannot identify him now.  I am not sure whether he is in here.
Fine.  Did you previously, before this Chesterville incident, participate in any operations or projects of Vlakplaas?
Do you know why Vlakplaas was requested by Durban Security to come to Natal?
No, I did not know that.  Even today I still do not know that.
Yes.  You say in your evidence-in-chief, you speculated that they normally go to taxi ranks and stations to look for terrorists.
Yes, that was their routine, that is what I knew.
You didn't come down from Vlakplaas to kill terrorists, it was purely to infiltrate?  Or didn't you know at all what the object was?
I do not understand your question, Sir.
Fine.  But you didn't know what the object was of coming to Natal?

I was not requested to do that, I was just given an instruction.  They couldn't go and fetch me specifically to tell me that you should come and be involved in something here, without going via de Kock.
Now the talk to infiltrate the UDF, you didn't personally hear that, that is purely from hearsay?
I heard de Kock telling the people who were involved in the Chesterville incident.  Which one was a hearsay?  I do not understand your question.
Fine.  Were you present in the room when instructions were given how to infiltrate the UDF?
Yes, I was present, but I was present when this infiltration was mentioned.
Was it in a room at CR Swart Police Station, where was it?
It is the place where we were sleeping, that is CR Swart.
Yes.  Was it in a conference hall, was it in an office, where was it?
It was a big room.  I am not sure whether it was a conference hall or what, but we were sleeping in that particular room.
So this meeting was held where everybody was sleeping, in the bedroom?
Yes, as I've already explained that, Sir.
And who was given instructions to infiltrate?
I said Mr de Kock mentioned that, telling the people who were supposed to go there.
Simon Radebe, Tandi Shosha, Susan Moekwena, I cannot remember the other one.  And the other people whose names I cannot remember.
And obviously there were no white members involved at all?
There was Nortje and the others whose names I cannot remember also.
What job did de Kock have for you?
I was with him, I was his driver, I was driving the car that he was in.
But you say that day had another job for you.  Can you remember what the job was?

Not on that particular day.  He said there was another mission that I should be involved in, that was myself and Geoffrey Bosigo.  He did not want us to be involved in that Chesterville mission because there was another mission for us.
So why were you present at this meeting?
I just found myself in there, in that room, while he was telling these people.  He did not order me to go out, he just came and talked.
Now the way you gave your evidence-in-chief, it seems that there was a report-back that the infiltration was successful and then a second operation launched, is that correct?
Did this all happen on the same day?
No, I cannot say, I think there was two to three days difference, it did not take place in one day.
But why can't you say?  The evidence that I will lead from Mr Vermeulen will testify that this all happened in one night.
That is what he remembers and that is what I can remember.  What I'm saying is actually what I can remember.
Yes, well I want to find out if you're telling us the truth.  Did this happen in a day or did it happen in two to three days?
As I've already explained, that is what I can remember, it did not take place in one day.
But you cannot deny if Vermeulen and Nortje and Bosch would testify and say that this happened in one night, the infiltration and the second operation.
And I cannot admit that because I cannot remember that.

Yes.  Then you must testify before the Committee and say you cannot remember.  Now the evidence would be that an order was given that an infiltration should take place and that the comrades then wanted a showpiece in the form an AK47, to see that they were true MK cadres ...(intervention)
Excuse me, will the speaker repeat the question.
Sorry I've got to repeat the question.  You see, my client will testify that you were not at the scene at the bridge.

Sorry, Mr Cornelius, can I just ask you to complete that first phrase that you were busy with when the interpreter asked you to repeat it.  You say that the comrades wanted a showpiece in the form of an AK47, to test the bona fides if the infiltrators.  Would that be right?

Correct, Mr Chair.  Well let me complete that question just for proper sequence.  My client will testify that the comrades wanted a showpiece in the form of an AK47, and that is why the AK47 was given to Simon Radebe.  Can you comment on that?

Yes, I can say it comes to me as a surprise it it's put that way because from Vlakplaas, this AK47 was from Vlakplaas up to Durban. I do not understand how did they know that these comrades were going to need this AK47, so that these people can take it all the way from Vlakplaas up to Durban.
Tell us about the AK47, who drew the AK47 at Vlakplaas?
I do not know, but I know that there were AK47 rifles in Vlakplaas and even this one was coming from Vlakplaas.  That is what I think.
But tell us, how do you know that this AK47 comes from Vlakplaas?  Explain that to us.
I said that is what I think, it was coming from Vlakplaas because they would carry them to the car and take them with wherever they go.  As far as I think, this also was coming from Vlakplaas.
Yes, but you are speculating, Mr Nofomela, don't think where the weapon came from.  Was an AK47 taken from Vlakplaas or not?
I do not know where it came from.
Yes, but why don't you testify that, why do you state as a certainty it came from Vlakplaas, and now you don't know where it came from?
That is what I am saying because all the time there would be AK47 rifles that were taken with and handgrenades were taken with.  I am saying this from experience.
Yes, yes, but we are talking about one isolated incident now.  Are you saying there were handgrenades as well, or is that just part of your speculation?

I am not saying that, but you asked for my comment.  You did not want me to be specific, but you just wanted me to comment to the statement.  Then if you reject that, do not say that that is the confirmation that I have.  I am not saying for sure, but I was just commenting as you had asked me.
That's a crafty legal argument.  Where was this AK47 given to Simon Radebe - who was the AK47 given to, do you know?
I do not remember who gave it to him, but Nortje was also involved in distributing the firearms.
Yes, now where did this distribution take place?
At the base, at CR Swart.
Prior to leaving that night, when you drove the kombi with the member in, is that correct or not?
Can the speaker please repeat the question.
Was that prior to you leaving and driving the members in the kombi or not?
How many pistols were given out, do you know?
But normally you find that the policemen at Vlakplaas are issues with their own weapons, why was it necessary at this incident to hand out handguns?
Some of them were askaris, therefore they were not handling any firearms.
And you say the AK47 rifle was also given at CR Swart to Simon Radebe?
I said I do not know to whom it was given, but I saw it when it was given out.
But you can't remember who gave the weapons out, was it de Kock?
I have already said that I remember very well that Mr Nortje was involved in the distributing of firearms and I do not know to whom did he give a particular weapon.
But Nortje didn't keep the AK47 for himself, he gave it out to somebody, according to your testimony.
Yes.  Because it's strange you know, Nortje in his amnesty application says that he gave the AK47 to Simon Radebe at the bridge.
But he has no reason to lie about it, do you agree?
What could be the reason for him not to lie?
Yes, if the weapon was given at the bridge, it was given at the bridge, why would he deny that?
Where did I say that?  Because I saw him giving it to one of them who was going to shoot.  He was given the AK47 at the base next to the Dog Unit.
Can you think of any reason why Mr Eugene de Kock did not apply for amnesty for this case, this incident?
That question can be directed to him, Sir.
Yes, but you will find it strange because he's applied in various other instances for amnesty, but not in this one.
I don't think that concerns me, Sir.
Well I'll give you the answer.  It's because Mr de Kock says that at that time, when this incident took place, when the shooting took place, he was sleeping, he was at CR Swart, the base camp.
Sleeping at the CR Swart base?
Do you have a problem in following my statement?
No, I do not understand, just repeat it please.
You just repeated it for me, you said yes, sleeping at the base.  Are you surprised at my statement?
Yes.  Now is Mr de Kock lying when he says he was sleeping at the base when the shooting incident took place?
Why?  Why should he lie about it, he was not present and there's four other witnesses that can testify to that.

I am saying he was present, I wouldn't be with him whereas I was under his - I wouldn't be there with him and join the other people, coming all the way from Vlakplaas under his jurisdiction and join the other people, without being instructed by them.  I was not under Nortje and the others here in Durban, I was under Mr de Kock.  Therefore everything - he was my commander, he's the one who was supposed to tell me that join these people or just stay.  If he was asleep, what would I be doing there transporting the people without getting an instruction from him?
That's a very elaborate answer, but Mr Vermeulen, Mr Nortje, Mr Bosch, Mr Frank McCarter, will testify that de Kock was not at the scene.
Now are you saying they're lying?
As far as I am concerned they are lying.
It might be that you're mistaken.
No, I'm not mistaken, I am sure, I am certain.
And furthermore, my client will deny that there was ever an instruction issued to kill the comrades.  Do you have any comment on that?
Will you please repeat the question, Sir.
My client as well as the witnesses, will deny that there was ever an instruction issued that the comrades should be killed.

I can say I don't know why should I bother myself making an application, knowing very well that people were going to be killed whereas I would be lying.  I do not know why would I make that application, not unless I am insane.  How did I know that people were going to be killed if the people were not going to be killed?
You testified in the Supreme Court against Mr de Kock, is that correct?
Please elaborate on that, about what?  About this Chesterville incident or what?
Did you testify against Mr de Kock in the Supreme Court?
And do you remember remarks by the judge regarding perjury?
No, I do not remember, please remind me.

I will control the record and then I will, with the consent of the Committee, put those questions from the record to you at a later stage.  Now when de Kock said you should not go to the scene because people will be shot, could it be that it was said that it's a dangerous situation where you should not be involved in?
A dangerous situation, do you mean that it could be that he was protecting me?  I do not understand your question, Sir.
Yes, that he was protecting you, saying that you shouldn't be involved in the operations of Vlakplaas.

He was not protecting me, he told me that there was another assignment for myself and Geoffrey Bosigo and that particular mission we should be involved in, we should be excluded in this Chesterville incident.  That was the reason for me not to be involved.  That was the only reason he gave to me.
The fact that there was a shooting at the scene, that was hearsay evidence that you heard, is that correct?

Why do you say in your evidence-in-chief
"If my memory serves me well, they went to the place and heard gunshots."
Are you in doubt about what hearsay evidence you heard?

I am saying I knew that shooting was going to take place before transporting these people to the incident.  I knew what was going to happen.  As we were waiting there under the bridge, plus-minus 30 minutes, I heard gunshots.  That's what I'm saying.
Did you hear the - now the gunshots you heard, was it a single shot, was it bursts of gunshots, what?
As I've already explained, I heard that the people were firing.
I cannot demonstrate, but I heard that they were firing.

"Magage and Radebe and the new recruits were issued with AK47 firearms by Major de Kock."

I'm still looking.  Yes, I can see that.

That is Mr de Wet, he told the Commission about our situation while we were doing consultations.  That is one of the issues that was a result of that, that all the points here are not as reflected as they were supposed to be.
So are you saying this is a mistake of your legal representative?

That is not a mistake from my legal representative.  I am saying because we did not have enough time for consultation, we were doing things in a hurry and some of the things could have escaped my mind.
According to you, when the instructions were issued to kill the comrades, what was said?
As I've already said, de Kock told me that those people were going to be shot at.
But you weren't present when the instructions were - the so-called instructions were given?
De Kock told me not to be involved because that was going to happen and he still wanted to use me on another mission, though he did not tell me about it.
You weren't present when the instructions were issued to kill the comrades ...(intervention)

Mr Chairman, I think the evidence - according to the evidence, the applicant has never said that de Kock instructed the members to shoot, he said that Mr de Kock told him that the people were going to get shot.  So he never testified about the instruction that was given to the people to be shot.

Yes, perhaps we can clarify that, because that's what Mr Cornelius was dealing with.
	Did you hear Mr de Kock give any instructions to the group that went into Chesterville?  - about shooting the targets.
That did not happen in my presence, but he told me about that.

Thank you, Mr Chairman.
	So you don't know what the firsthand instructions to the members were?
Thank you.  It could be that it was said to you that you should not go because people could get shot.  In other words, that he was protecting you.

Sir, when I was responding to some questions you told me not to speculate.  I am telling you that he was not protecting me, he was just telling me not to be there because I was to be involved in some assignment.  Why did he not protect all of them, why did he choose me to protect?
Let me see if I can clear it up for you.  At that time the situation in the townships were very explosive, it was dangerous times in '86.
I do not understand what was dangerous, where?
Well there were Self-Protection Units running around, fighting, there were A-teams, there were comrades, there were lots of dangerous situations in the townships at that time.
Yes.  And Mr de Kock could have meant that you should not go with because you could get hurt.

Sir, he told me that people were going to be shot at and he would even tell me not to go there because I was going to be hurt and then he would take a newly recruited askari and leave me behind, a person who has experience, and try to protect me.
